qas.question: How long does it take glaciers to form?
Do glaciers form on land, in the sea, or a combination of both?
Which types of ice form on a body of water's surface?
What causes glaciers to deform and flow?
What are some distinguishing glacial features?
What is a semi-permanent body of ice that moves under its own weight?
What causes glaciers to remain smooth in uniform?
What other kinds of ice are thicker than glaciers?

context: A <b5_0><b6_0>glacier<b6_0/><b5_0/> (US /ˈɡleɪʃər/ or UK /ˈɡlæsiə/) is a persistent body of dense ice that is constantly moving under its own weight; it forms where the accumulation of snow exceeds its ablation (melting and sublimation) over <a0_0>many years, often centuries<a0_0/>. Glaciers slowly deform and flow due to <a3_0>stresses induced by <b7_0>their weight<b7_0/><a3_0/>, creating <a4_0>crevasses, seracs<a4_0/>, and other distinguishing features. They also abrade rock and debris from their substrate to create landforms such as cirques and moraines. Glaciers form <a1_0>only on land<a1_0/> and are distinct from the much thinner <a2_0><b8_0>sea ice and lake ice<b8_0/><a2_0/> that form on the surface of bodies of water.
